Support for democracy in Latin America continues to grow, as private enterprise.
The crime has become a greater concern than unemployment.
And Brazil is seen as more influential than the United States in much of the region.
These are some of the conclusions of the latest Latinobarómetro poll taken in 18 countries and published exclusively by The Economist.
Since the survey was conducted on a regular basis since 1995, it tracks changes in attitude in the region.
Two elements emerge from the results of the survey of this year, conducted in September and early October.
The first is the sunny mood of Latin America.
The second is the increasing stability of attitudes toward democracy and its key institutions.
Support for democracy has increased significantly in several countries on the Pacific rim of South America (see table 1).
For example in Peru, where economic growth has averaged 6% per year since 2002, support for democracy from a minimum of 40% in 2005 to 61% this year.
It has also increased in Mexico, where the economy has rebounded after a sharp drop in production last year.
But only about half of the respondents in Mexico and Brazil, the two most populous countries in the region, are convinced democrats, which lowers the regional average (see table 2).

Some 44% of respondents in the region expressed satisfaction with the way democracy in their country worked in practice; it is the same figure as last year but with a sharp increase on the 25% in 2001 (Chart 3)
Some 34% said they had confidence in the parliament of their country and 45% in their government, the same as last year in both cases, but up sharply compared to 2003 (17% and 24% respectively).
Ten years ago, the economic problems in Latin America have undermined support for democracy.
If it has held good during the global financial crisis, it is certainly due to the fact that many countries have suffered only a brief recession and have benefited from a strong recovery.
In addition, a network of social security has helped to protect the poor.
(The United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America reported this week that the proportion of Latin Americans living in poverty increased only slightly in 2009 and again this year, to 32%.)
But the mood varies considerably from one country to another (see chart 4).
The good economic performance of Brazil and the popularity of its outgoing president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, a widely shared sense of progress
What is more rare in Mexico and Central America, where the recession was more severe and where violent crimes have increased.

It is only the second time since the survey began that more respondents across Latin America as a whole have cited the crime rather than unemployment as the most important issue for their country (see table 5).
About 31% say they or their have been the victim of a criminal act in the past year, however, this figure is down from 38% last year and is the lowest since 1995.

A more robust economic performance is reflected in the increase in support for private enterprise and the market economy: About 71% of respondents in the region say that private enterprise is essential for development, against 56% in 2007 (see Chart 6).
Some 58% believe that the market economy is the only system that will make their developed country, against 47% last year.
Interestingly, 62% of respondents in Venezuela are of this opinion (and 80% support private enterprise); even if their president, Hugo Chavez, expropriated many private companies.
Brazil is the greatest leader in the region, mentioned by 19% of respondents (18% last year), followed by the United States (9%, unchanged from last year) and Venezuela (9%, down 11% since last year)

But the United States are considered the most influential country by respondents in Mexico and in much of Central America, while Venezuela has this distinction in Ecuador, the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua.

p.seg: A half-dozen of them were typing away in the rows of the courtroom.

But lawyers for Mr. Hayes have already filed to the court that outline arguments of appeal, likely to occupy the courts for years.

What is provocative, it is that the intense coverage of the trial - as well as the widespread use and extended by journalists of the Twitter - have created a "circus atmosphere," so widespread and instant saturation with incendiary details that the jury was improperly influenced by the passions of the public.
The demand could push the judges to debate on the question of whether new technologies require new rules in the courtroom.

"I have experience at this trial, I think there is a real danger, the introduction of new technologies in the courtroom violates the rights of the person to a fair trial," said Thomas J. Ullmann, lawyer for Mr. Hayes, chief lawyer.

The trial judge, Jon c. Blue of state Superior Court, has rejected the claims in the ruling last week, saying that the media were "carefully controlled" and that there was no evidence that the jury would have been facilitated by the passion.
But that does not seem to be the last word on the issue.
The courts have recognized for decades that the media coverage of notorious cases may raise questions about the fairness of a trial.

In a judgment of 1966 landmark, the Supreme Court of the United States overturned the conviction of an osteopath of Cleveland, Dr. Sam Sheppard, for the murder of his wife, arguing in its decision that there was a "carnival atmosphere at the trial" because of the media.
The crime is considered by some to have been the inspiration for the television show and movie "The Fugitive."

Some lawyers said that the appellate courts to review a half a century later the conviction of Mr. Hayes may be curious given the argument that new rules could be needed to manage the means of communication of courtrooms, unimaginable at the time of the case of Dr. Sheppard.

"There is a general reason to worry about the impact of new media" in the large-scale trials, said John j. Donohue III, a professor at the Stanford Law School who has studied the death penalty in Connecticut and wrote a report that she was arbitrarily applied.
Professor Donohue said that some judges could be intrigued by the idea that the limitation of instant communication from the courtrooms could allow fairer trial.
The case of Twitter is only one of many described by lawyers for Mr. Hayes, likely to be discussed for years, delaying the execution.

The defense lawyers also say, for example, that Mr. Hayes would have suffered injury when the judge refused to allow them to test the reactions of potential jurors by showing grisly photos of crime scenes in the selection of the jury.
Some of the jurors said they were horrified by the pictures of the victims, Jennifer Hawke-Petit, 48, and her daughters, Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11 years.

The defense lawyers say they will also challenge the constitutionality of the death penalty and that they will argue that the judge unfairly expelled one juror, who had been critical to the prosecutors, and that he improperly put pressure for a verdict by taking the unusual step of bringing the jury to deliberate in a weekend.
The jurors were not sequestered.
But their arguments on the effect of the intense media coverage of the trial could be the greatest source of interest.

They noted in a protest against the verdict, filed last month, that the case dominated the media scene in Connecticut and it was discussed during the election campaign by the candidates for governor and the Senate of the United States.
They maintained that the computer media kept fanning the flames of the emotion of the case.
"The daily tweets of media, cameras and journalists to the courthouse," the lawyers wrote, "not unlike anything that had been seen before here in New Haven, and perhaps even at the national level."
Their focus on the cover of the Twitter system is controversial.

In interviews, some journalists said that the claim that the instant news were more incendiary than delivered more slowly, was a luddiste that would impoverish the court's policy governing media coverage of the future trials.
But some lawyers said that the Courts of Appeal étaitent often attracted by the arguments that the social and technological changes required an adaptation by the courts.

hl.seg: The veterans of the Khmer Rouge forced to confront the past

p.seg: In a poorly lit classroom with concrete walls of poor quality, the director of the school of Anlong Veng evoked the man who had built, the last Khmer Rouge leader, Ta Mok.
"Everyone here loves Ta Mok."
"It was a good leader; and he cared about his people," said Sreng Kor Ma, 42.

Known as "The Butcher" for his brutality, when he was the head of the Khmer Rouge, the commander remains popular in this isolated bastion of former Khmer Rouge in northwestern Cambodia where he has built hospitals, bridges and other infrastructure; and where thousands of former soldiers of the organization still live today.
But this year, 12 years after the Khmer Rouge went to the government, the loyalty is finally challenged in Anlong Veng.
In April, a local forum of Truth and Reconciliation allowed victims to respond publicly to the people who had participated in the scheme.
In June, the government has distributed a manual of high school, which for the first time, teaches the history of the Khmer Rouge to the children of former soldiers.

And, in July, a Cambodian court, jointly run with the United Nations, made its first sentence for a former member of the Khmer Rouge, condemning, to 35 years in prison, the former head of the notorious Tuol Sleng torture center, Kaing Khek Iev, better known as "Duch."
In this situation, the increased anxiety among veterans of the Khmer Rouge in Anlong Veng, complicating the efforts of reconciliation and their wishes to reintegrate into Cambodian society.

"There is resentment and fear among the former Khmer Rouge but they are powerless to do anything," said Youk Chhang, director of the Documentation Center of Cambodia, an independent organization that conducts research on the regime.
"For them, life under the Khmer Rouge was glorious but the regime has become a symbol of evil."
"The situation creates divisions within families."
Under the reign of the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, from 1975 to 1979, about 1.7 million people were executed or died of starvation, disease or overwork.
When the Vietnamese invaded and overthrew the government of Pol Pot-United in 1979, the rest of the regime and its army fled to the border with Thailand.
There, they launched an insurgency that lasted until the last movements in December 1998.
While Pol Pot, Nuon Chea and Ieng Sary led the guerrillas from their base in the mountains of western Cambodia and in the jungle, Ta Mok was preparing a response to Anlong Veng.

But in the mid-1990s, after a peace agreement sponsored by the UN has led to the country's first democratic elections in 1993, large groups of Khmer Rouge fighters began to defect to the government, culminating with the capitulation of Ieng Sary in 1996 and Nuon Chea and Khieu Samphan in 1998.
Pol Pot died of natural causes in 1998 and Ta Mok, who had stood up, was captured by government forces in 1999 in the mountains near Dangrek.
He died in a prison in Phnom Penh in 2006 pending his trial.
Without their benefactors, most of the Khmer Rouge veterans have sunk into abject poverty, common in rural areas of Cambodia; and many remain nostalgic for the movement.
Although some elite officers Khmer Rouge kept their posts in local leader in exchange for having laid down their arms, it is farmers in low rank and file.

"These people have benefited very little follow-up after the capitulation," said Sok Leang of the Centre for Justice and Reconciliation, which organizes public forums throughout Cambodia, including Anlong Veng.
"They are soaked in the agrarian utopian ideology of the regime."
"They were raised in an environment where business is a foreign concept."
Sor Lim, 55, who joined the Khmer Rouge as a teenager in 1974, fought in the jungle around Anlong Veng before settling in 1998 as poor rice farmer.
"Life under the Khmer Rouge was good," he said.
"Ta Mok feeds everyone."
But now, life is difficult because we must meet our own needs. "
The Khmer Rouge tribunal has also caused worries here.
The court should, at the beginning of next year, to begin the trial of Nuon Chea, Khieu Samphan, Ieng Sary and his wife, Ieng Thirith, another former Khmer Rouge minister.
The mandate of the Tribunal is to try senior leaders and those most responsible for the crimes but he has not said if he continued beyond these four cases.
It would be more to calm fears in Anlong Veng.
The recent media speculation turned to IM Chaem, aged 64, former chief of district in the province of Banteay Meanchey under the reign of the Khmer Rouge in the 1970s.
In 2007, she said the researchers of the Documentation Center of Cambodia that she had supervised the construction of the dam Trapeang thma, a project where thousands of forced labourers were killed.
Recently, at a torrid evening, Im Chaem home from work in the field near his wooden house on stilts, on a dirt road outside Anlong Veng.
As the sun cast long shadows on the grass, Im Chaem refused to discuss his past in the Khmer Rouge.
If the court convened, she said, she would refuse to go there.
"Cambodia is at peace and stable," she said.
"If there are more prosecutions, there will be war."

Prime Minister Hun Sen, who defected from the Khmer Rouge in 1978, has also repeatedly warned that instability would occur if the court had several suspects, although experts and historians dispute this.
"Cambodia to dig a hole and bury the past," he said.
But the past is that Cambodia must do to move forward, said Youk Chhang, of the Documentation Centre.
"Reconciliation in Khmer is to reconnect the broken pieces," he said.
"We must put these pieces together so that we can understand."
The center has produced the first textbook approved by the Government on the Khmer Rouge, "a history of Democratic Kampuchea, consisting of 75 pages."
It was distributed to Anlong Veng in June as a supplement to the history textbooks of the Ministry of Education, designed for high schools, which contained less than four pages on the Khmer Rouge.
As in most of Cambodia, the young Anlong Veng know only a few details about the Khmer Rouge, despite the links of the city to the regime.
Touch Valeak, 19, a student at the high school in Anlong Veng, said that the new manual was helping students understand an important part of their history.
But his parents have reacted with skepticism when he returned with the book home to study.
"My family rejects many parts of the Manual and the court," he said.
"They are wary because they do not know exactly how many people the court will continue."
Such resistance has made the process of reconciliation complex and difficult, "said Sok Leang.
But public forums, the manual and the Court are beginning to have an impact, "he said.
However, the Khmer Rouge retain a powerful atrait here.
IN THE MOUNTAINS OF Dangrek, a road, overgrown with weeds and strewn with plastic bags, led to a rectangle of black soot, covered with a rusty tin roof.
The body of Pol Pot was burned here on a pile of tires after his death in 1998.
Nuom Sothea, aged 31, of Mobile Phone roadside, said that she did not know much about the man who was cremated at this location.
"But it has a great spirit; and many people go there to pray," she said.
It was the anniversary of Nuom Sothea and, later that day, she planned to walk towards the final resting place of Pol Pot where it would leave a bouquet of ripe bananas in the hope of bringing luck.

hl.seg: Belarus agrees to waive its stock of weapons-grade uranium

p.seg: The Government of Belarus announced Wednesday that it would abandon its stock of highly enriched uranium, an essential component for nuclear weapons; this is part of a surprise victory of the campaign of President Obama to secure nuclear materials around the world

The agreement was disclosed in a joint statement issued after the Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton met the foreign minister of Belarus, Sergei Martynov, on the sidelines of a summit on security.
The US government had tried for years to convince Belarus to give up highly enriched uranium and seemed to have cleared the horizon last spring.

But US officials told The Washington Post that some classified operations were conducted with Belarus over the last two months to eliminate 187 pounds of weapons-grade uranium from a research centre of Belarus.

This opened the way for an agreement Wednesday to eliminate the rest of the field of about 500 pounds, according to an official who spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue.
The agreement appears to be one of the most important results of the Nuclear Security Summit of 47 nations, organized at the initiative of Obama; where Belarus was excluded.
Apparently, it was good to get an invitation to the former Soviet republic following the summit in 2012.
"I am really fascinated by the fact that they want a seat at the nuclear security summit in 2012 nuclear security summit."
"This proves to me that this process works," said Ken Luongo, president of the Partnership for Global Security, a group of nuclear safety.
Clinton called the agreement "very significant, important" by Belarus.
Obama has pledged to Prague in April 2009 to secure all vulnerable nuclear materials around the world within four years.
Since then, the U.S. government has helped six countries to get rid of all its highly enriched uranium.
Belarus would be the seventh.
A dozen countries have been under the administration of George W. Bush.
At the time of the summit on nuclear safety of Obama, the Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, said that the nation would never abandon its uranium.
"We kept the highly enriched uranium, hundreds of kilograms of what is essentially the weapons-grade uranium and low-enriched uranium," said Mr Lukashenko.
"This is our product ... we are not going to make dirty bombs, and we will sell it to anyone."
"We will use it for research purposes, that is all."
Belarus has approached the United States a few months ago; however, expressing interest in reaching an agreement.
The first implementation to remove uranium from Belarus, in October, was particularly complicated because the material had been slightly irradiated, officials said.
It was loaded on a special train that ran more than 1,300 miles to a facility in Russia to be stored and eliminated, officials said.
The second operation was completed Monday and was carried by air, according to the officials.
The US government spent $13 million in its efforts, in large part to replace the research facilities of Belarus with low enriched uranium; unsuitable for weapons.

"A careful coordination and organization have been implemented in order to strengthen confidence," leading to the agreement signed by Clinton, said Andrew Bieniawski, head of the Department of Energy in the threat.
According to estimates by the Center for Study of James Martin, Belarus had this year at least 88 pounds of weapons-grade uranium, as well as hundreds of kilograms of highly enriched uranium.
Belarus seeks to eliminate its stockpiles by 2012, according to a joint statement.
Relations between Belarus and the United States are strained for years, mainly because of the harsh repression by Lukashenko of human rights.
But the statement Wednesday suggested a potential revival.

"While welcoming the progress on these issues of global security, the United States and Belarus have recognized that a greater respect for democracy and human rights in Belarus remained essential to improve bilateral relations; and essential to the progress of the country and its citizens," she said.
